H0.text: Reactors are the nuclear devices that can use only a few of the numerous elements capable of undergoing fission as fuels.

H1.text: Colliders are nuclear devices that use only a few elements capable of fission as fuels, even though numerous elements can undergo fission.

H2.text: Laser beams are the nuclear devices in which only a few fissionable elements can be used as fuels, even though many elements can undergo fission.

H3.text: Accelerators are nuclear devices in which only a few elements that can undergo fission can be used as fuels, even though many elements can undergo fission.

A4.text: Almost all current reactors are thermal-neutron reactors that use low-enriched uranium or natural uranium fuel.

A5.text: Breeder reactors convert fertile U-238 to Pu-239 or Th-232 to U-233, indicating that reactors rely on a limited set of fissile materials.
